nodes.text: Agents maximize the time-average growth rate of wealth and expected utility theory can be interpreted as a representation of this growth optimality by identifying the utility function with the ergodicity transformation of the wealth dynamics
Ergodicity economics (EE) posits that individual decision makers care about time averages of wealth trajectories rather than ensemble expectation values

Expected utility theory (EUT) models agents as maximizing expectation values of a nonlinear transformation of wealth called the utility function and treats utility as a psychological, exogenously chosen mapping

There exists a correspondence: for wealth dynamics that admit an ergodicity transformation, the time-average growth rate equals the expectation value of changes in that transformation, so identifying the transformation with utility makes EUT decisions equivalent to time-optimal decisions

All invertible utility functions correspond to wealth dynamics for which maximization of expected utility is growth optimal, i.e. every invertible u(x) encodes a unique wealth stochastic differential equation

Time averages and expectation values coincide only for ergodic observables; wealth increments in many economic settings are non-ergodic so expectation values lack mechanistic relevance for single agents
EE models wealth as a stochastic process with dynamics specified exogenously to preferences and chooses the ergodicity transformation u(x) to extract a time-average growth rate from that process

If the transformed quantity u(t) has stationary, independent additive increments then r = delta u / delta t is ergodic and its time average equals its expectation; processes with continuous paths imply u(t) is Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW

The decision criterion of choosing the process that with high probability yields larger wealth in the long-time limit can be recast as maximizing the long-run rate r = lim delta u / delta t for a monotonic transformation u(x)

Applying Ito calculus: given an invertible twice-differentiable u(x) with du following Brownian motion with drift, one can derive the corresponding Ito SDE for wealth x(t) and thereby obtain a family of dynamics consistent with that utility
Central theoretical result: EUT is equivalent to time optimization only if utility follows an additive stochastic process with stationary increments, taken here as Brownian motion with drift

Examples: linear u(x)=x maps to additive Brownian wealth dynamics; logarithmic u(x)=ln x maps to geometric Brownian motion; square-root u(x)=sqrt(x) maps to mixed additive-multiplicative dynamics with noise amplitude proportional to sqrt(x)

Given u(t) Gaussian (Brownian) one can derive wealth distributions Px(x,t) by change of variables Px(x,t)=Pu(u(x),t) du/dx, enabling direct computation of population wealth distributions from assumed u(x)

Implication: since wealth dynamics are exogenous, apparent utility functions and thus observed risk preferences are predicted by the dynamics and will change if dynamics change, contradicting the standard assumption of fixed preferences

Experimental and historical support: previous work and experiments with controllable wealth dynamics indicate that dynamics strongly determine preferences and that mapping utility to ergodicity transformation resolves interpretive circularity in EUT

Limitation and formal requirement: this dynamic interpretation requires invertible and effectively unbounded utility functions so that u(x) can be inverted to x(u) and u(t) can follow unbounded Brownian motion with drift; bounded u(x) are mathematically problematic in this framework
